TextEquiv.Unicode: the Church of the people of the new te
stament, had ever since ye time of Christ
and the Apostles, goods and possessions
publikely gathered and received, and
also layde out and bestowed them a
gaine for publique and common com
moditie.
Gregorie the first of that name, bi
shoppe of Rome, sayth that it was the
custome in his time and also before his
time, that there ought to be foure por
tions or parts of the church of God.
One for the bishop and his familie,
another for the clergy, the third for the
poore, and the fourth for the repayring
of Churches,
But there are a great many that say
that a bishoppe ought not to receive
wages of ye church. Let us therfore ex
amine what Christ and his Apostles do
teach us touching that matter. Christ
our Lorde, who never committed anie
uniust thing, received, as it is reade,
maintenance from such women as he
taught, who ministred unto him of
their substace. He also sending his dis
ciples abroad, and willing them not to
be carefull for meate and drinke, and
raiment, saith further, The labourer is
worthie of his hire.
The Lord judgeth it to be worthie,
meete, & right, to minister necessaries
unto preachers. Wherefore they do no
unworthy deede which receive wages,
thereby to provide necessaries for them
selves and their family: yea, he compa
reth preachers not to idle bellies, not to
them ye eate freely of other mens bread,
neither to beggers, but to laborers. For
as ye Lord setteth down in ye law, how
that it is a great offence to deny labo
rers their hireeven so their offence is
not small ye suffer such as are faithfull
feeders of the flocke, to perish and decay
through need. For in another place the
Lord speketh to his disciples saying, Te

the Church of the people of the new te stament, had ever since ye time of Christ and the Apostles, goods and possessions publikely gathered and received, and also layde out and bestowed them a gaine for publique and common com moditie. Gregorie the first of that name, bi shoppe of Rome, sayth that it was the custome in his time and also before his time, that there ought to be foure por tions or parts of the church of God. One for the bishop and his familie, another for the clergy, the third for the poore, and the fourth for the repayring of Churches, But there are a great many that say that a bishoppe ought not to receive wages of ye church. Let us therfore ex amine what Christ and his Apostles do teach us touching that matter. Christ our Lorde, who never committed anie uniust thing, received, as it is reade, maintenance from such women as he taught, who ministred unto him of their substace. He also sending his dis ciples abroad, and willing them not to be carefull for meate and drinke, and raiment, saith further, The labourer is worthie of his hire. The Lord judgeth it to be worthie, meete, & right, to minister necessaries unto preachers. Wherefore they do no unworthy deede which receive wages, thereby to provide necessaries for them selves and their family: yea, he compa reth preachers not to idle bellies, not to them ye eate freely of other mens bread, neither to beggers, but to laborers. For as ye Lord setteth down in ye law, how that it is a great offence to deny labo rers their hireeven so their offence is not small ye suffer such as are faithfull feeders of the flocke, to perish and decay through need. For in another place the Lord speketh to his disciples saying, Te
have freely received it, and therefore
give it freely. But he speaketh of ye gift
of working miracles, & of the benefite
of health to be bestowed upon the fick,
diseased, and oppressed. For thus it is
written: Heale the sicke, cleanse the
leaprous, raise the dead, cast out de,
vils. And to these words he added this,
saying: Te have received it freely, and
therefore bestowe it freely. Therefore
though ye Apostles received rewarde of
the to whom they preached: yet never
any man read that ever they tooke any
thing for the gift of healing which they
received in ye Lords name. Like as He
liseus would not take any thing at all
though it were freely offered him by
Naaman the Syrian captaine, for that
by his counsel he was healed of the le
prosie. Pet the self same Heliseus refu
sed not the gift of the man that came
unto him from Baalsalisa. Out of the
selfe same Gospell of Christ our Lord,
Ministers have to learne to what use
they ought to put ye wages they have
of the church. For what time the Lord
commaunded Judas who carried the
purse, to depart, the residue of the disci
ples thought that he had beene coman
ded to go and buy such necessaries as
should serue for the holy day, or else to
bestowsomething on the poore. There
fore it is plain that the Lord used with
ye stipend which he received, to provide
necessaries for him and his, and also
to give almes therof, Marke well then
that the ministers of the Church may
provide thinges necessarie for their li
ving, function, and maintenance of
their housholde, of the wages they re
ceive of the church. Againe, they may
also of the same wages give almes un
to the poore, even as it were of their
owne goods truly gotten. For the Lord
saith plainly in the law, that the sacri
fice of the Levites made of tythes, and

have freely received it, and therefore give it freely. But he speaketh of ye gift of working miracles, & of the benefite of health to be bestowed upon the fick, diseased, and oppressed. For thus it is written: Heale the sicke, cleanse the leaprous, raise the dead, cast out de, vils. And to these words he added this, saying: Te have received it freely, and therefore bestowe it freely. Therefore though ye Apostles received rewarde of the to whom they preached: yet never any man read that ever they tooke any thing for the gift of healing which they received in ye Lords name. Like as He liseus would not take any thing at all though it were freely offered him by Naaman the Syrian captaine, for that by his counsel he was healed of the le prosie. Pet the self same Heliseus refu sed not the gift of the man that came unto him from Baalsalisa. Out of the selfe same Gospell of Christ our Lord, Ministers have to learne to what use they ought to put ye wages they have of the church. For what time the Lord commaunded Judas who carried the purse, to depart, the residue of the disci ples thought that he had beene coman ded to go and buy such necessaries as should serue for the holy day, or else to bestowsomething on the poore. There fore it is plain that the Lord used with ye stipend which he received, to provide necessaries for him and his, and also to give almes therof, Marke well then that the ministers of the Church may provide thinges necessarie for their li ving, function, and maintenance of their housholde, of the wages they re ceive of the church. Againe, they may also of the same wages give almes un to the poore, even as it were of their owne goods truly gotten. For the Lord saith plainly in the law, that the sacri fice of the Levites made of tythes, and
